title: Planned Parenthood rolls out vasectomies at Mass. health centers
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts now offers vasectomies, available initially at their Worcester health center.
Demand for permanent contraception like vasectomies has increased since the Dobbs decision in June 2022.
Vasectomy consultations are required at any of Planned Parenthood's four Massachusetts centers before the procedure.

title: Body of Eastham man who fell through ice located after days of searching
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: The body of Gerard 'Jerry' Boucher, 72, was found near Eastham's Bee's River after falling through the ice.
Jerry and Kathleen 'Kit' Boucher fell through ice at First Encounter Beach on February 14 while walking their dog.
Emergency crews searched for days; Kit Boucher's body was recovered the same morning they fell through the ice.

title: MSP trooper dragged by vehicle during East Boston stop
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: A Massachusetts State Police trooper was injured after being dragged 10 to 20 feet by a car in East Boston.
The driver, Binit Bikram Shah, 27, was later arrested in New Hampshire and showed signs of impairment, authorities said.
Shah faces multiple charges, including assault and battery with a dangerous weapon and drug-related offenses.

title: Here’s why readers support voter ID laws, even as some take issue with SAVE America Act
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: The SAVE America Act would require proof of citizenship and photo ID for federal election voting.
Massachusetts congresspeople oppose the bill, citing potential voter disenfranchisement and influence over midterm elections.
Boston.com readers are divided; some support voter ID laws, while others criticize the SAVE Act's restrictions.

title: Mack Hollins fell just short of a stat worth $400K in incentives. The Patriots paid it anyway.
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Mack Hollins fell four catches short of a 50-catch incentive due to injury but received a $400K bonus anyway.
The Patriots compensated Hollins with a bonus after he led in receiving yards in the AFC Championship and Super Bowl.
Hollins, 32, caught 46 passes for 550 yards and 2 touchdowns in his first season with the Patriots.

title: Why I’m running the Boston Marathon for charity after 9/11 — and what it means to me
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Matt Marino, 48, from New Jersey, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for the Webb Norden Foundation.
The Webb Norden Foundation supports children and young adults recovering from trauma, founded by Boston Marathon bombing survivors.
Marino, who experienced 9/11, chose the foundation to help others facing traumatic events while pursuing his marathon goals.

title: Treated at Mass. Eye and Ear as a teen, she’s now running the Boston Marathon to give back
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Mary Ellen Burt, 37, from Chelmsford, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for Mass Eye and Ear.
Burt was treated at Mass Eye and Ear as a teenager for sinus and septum issues, inspiring her marathon run.
She aims to raise funds and awareness for Mass Eye and Ear, appreciating their impact on patient care and innovation.

title: New Mass. and Cass recommendations could mark major shift in strategy
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Recommendations from a working group propose expanding police and case management teams, and establishing a specialty court for drug offenses.
Proposals represent a shift from harm reduction strategies, focusing more on treatment referrals and legal consequences for drug use.
Boston's proposals aim to integrate safety, judicial, and recovery efforts while moving away from harm reduction policies like needle programs.

title: Massachusetts is 1 of 4 states that lost private-sector jobs over the last five years
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Massachusetts lost about 24,000 private-sector jobs from January 2020 to March 2025, a 0.74% decline.
The state's GDP growth has lagged behind the national average since 2022, impacting economic resilience.
High costs and slow growth in key industries contribute to residents relocating to states like Florida and Texas.

title: What is happening with the Central Square sign?
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: The Central Square sign was removed for rehabilitation due to graffiti damage and will be reinstalled soon.
Artists Kenji Nakayama and Dylan Gough are refurbishing the sign, using its original metal plates and design elements.
A community party is planned for March 13 to celebrate the sign's return, featuring local collaborations and entertainment.
